1 Introduction
Biofactor stands as a leading innovator in the bio-fertilizer industry. We are committed to trans-
forming agricultural practices through the application of cutting-edge biotechnologies. Recog-
nizing the critical role of healthy soil in sustaining a robust food system, Biofactor empowers
farmers with scientifically-driven bio-fertilizer solutions. These solutions enrich soil health, en-
hance crop yields, and safeguard the well-being of future generations.
A Decade of Groundbreaking Innovation: For over a decade, Biofactor has been at the forefront
of agricultural innovation. We dedicate ourselves to understanding the evolving challenges
faced by modern farming. Our focus lies in developing bio-fertilizers and organic inputs that
address the critical issues of declining soil fertility and the impact of chemical fertilizers on
human health. Our meticulous formulations, created using revolutionary technologies, ensure
the efficient delivery of essential macro and micronutrients to crops.
Pioneering Research and Development: Biofactor maintains a state-of-the-art R&D laboratory,
recognized by the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research (DSIR), Government of
India. Our team of highly qualified scientists is dedicated to pioneering advancements in bio-
fertilizer technology. We hold eight patents and have developed 35 proprietary microbial strains,
all meticulously selected for their effectiveness in promoting soil health and crop growth.
Global Collaboration, Local Impact: Biofactor fosters a collaborative spirit, working closely
with leading agricultural universities and research institutions worldwide. This global perspec-
tive allows us to develop solutions tailored to the specific needs of diverse crops and regional
agricultural environments. We are proud to be a member of esteemed organizations such as
the Fertilizer Association of India (FAI) and the Indian Council of Agricultural Research -
Central Institute for Research on Cotton Textiles (ICAR-CIRCOT). These affiliations further
strengthen our commitment to supporting the agricultural community.
A Legacy of Excellence in Sustainable Solutions: Biofactor has established itself as a leader in
the global agricultural sector through continuous innovation and unwavering dedication to sus-
tainability. Our groundbreaking MAMSP technology revolutionizes nutrient delivery to plants
by converting them into micron-sized particles, enabling optimal nutrient uptake and promoting
exceptional growth and yield.
Building a Sustainable Future, Together: As Biofac Inputs expands its global reach, we remain
resolute in our commitment to promoting sustainable practices in agriculture, poultry, and live-
stock industries. We believe in empowering farmers with innovative solutions that enhance soil
health, improve crop quality, and ensure the long-term viability of our agricultural ecosystems.
Invitation to Collaboration: Biofactor invites you to join us in cultivating a healthier and more
sustainable future. Together, let’s leverage the power of bio-technology to nourish the Earth
for generations to come.

2 FAQ & Answers on Bio-Fertilizers
Q1. What are Bio-Fertilizers?A mixture of micro-organisms that are alive and provide
nutrients to crops of agricultural importance.
Q2. What is the necessity of using Bio-Fertilizers in Agriculture?Only 25–50% of nu-
trients (Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potash, Zinc, Iron) present in chemical fertilizers like
Urea, DAP, Super Phosphate, Zinc Sulphate are available to plants. The remaining 50–
75% of nutrients remain in neutral state in the soil. Only these nutrients can be supplied
to the plant through Bio-Fertilizers.
3
Q3. What are the benefits of using Bio-Fertilizers?•Assimilates nitrogen from the
air and dissolves phosphorus, potash, zinc, iron, and other nutrients in neutral state
of soil, providing them to plants.
•Reduces use of chemical fertilizers by 20–25% and increases yield by 15–20%.
•Micro-organisms release biochemicals near plant roots that are useful for growth.
•Protects plant from waterlogging.
•Prevents some soil-borne diseases.
•Increases the number of good micro-organisms in the soil.
Q4. What are nutrients to crops?A vital mixture of micro-organisms that absorb and
provide nutrients to crops of agricultural importance.
Q5. How to use Bio-Fertilizers?•Solid Bio-Fertilizers:Apply in soil during plough-
ing, seedbed preparation, furrow, in the seedling area, around the roots, and along
the furrow.
•Liquid Bio-Fertilizers:Spray through foliar application, seed dip, or through
drip irrigation.
Q6. What precautions should be taken while using Bio-Fertilizers?•Store Bio-Fertilizers
in cool places (do not expose to sunlight).
•Use within 6 months from the manufacturing date.
•Avoid mixing with chemical fertilizers and pesticides.
•Apply in moist soil for better results.
•The moisture content of the soil should be adequate at the time of application.
Q7. What are the causes for non-availability of Bio-Fertilizers?•Non-availability of
high-quality raw materials and microbial species.
•Lack of proper carrier materials.
•Lack of proper research facilities to suit local crop needs.
•Lack of Bio-Fertilizer manufacturing units with advanced technology.
•Non-availability of suitable bio-encapsulation methods for different nutrients.

OverviewAadhaar Gold is a granular-based biofertilizer consortium designed to enhance
soil fertility and crop productivity throughBio-Encapsulation Technology. It combines
nitrogen-fixing, phosphate-solubilizing, and potassium-mobilizing microorganisms in a single
product. The advanced encapsulation ensures long microbial shelf life, gradual release, and
compatibility with chemical fertilizers. It improves soil health, root strength, and tolerance to
abiotic stress while supporting sustainable crop nutrition.
Key Composition (Label Specs)
•Azotobacter:≥1×10 7 CFU/g
•Phosphate Solubilizing Bacteria (PSB):≥1×10 7 CFU/g
•Potassium Mobilizing Bacteria (KMB):≥1×10 7 CFU/g
•Total Viable Count:≥3×10 7 CFU/g of carrier
Mechanism of Action
•Fixes atmospheric nitrogen and converts soil-bound phosphorus and potassium into plant-
available forms.
•Bio-Encapsulation improves microbial stability and field performance.
•Gradual release ensures sustained nutrient availability.
•Strengthens rhizosphere activity and root nutrient uptake.
•Protects against abiotic stresses (drought, salinity, temperature).
Scientific PrincipleBased on Bio-Encapsulation Technology — encapsulated beneficial mi-
crobes remain viable longer, protected by organic coating that withstands field stress. Gradual
release enhances microbial activity and nutrient efficiency over time.

3.1.2 INM Chakra
INM-Chakra introduces bacterial consortium encapsulated in liquid form, offering a stable
source of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium. This consortium comprises a minimum of
1.5×10 7 bacteria per millilitre. It is specially formulated in liquid form for easy application in
the field.
Benefits:
•Collects nitrogen from the air, dissolves phosphorus, potash and other nutrients in neutral
state and returns them to plants.
•Number of good microorganisms increases→soil fertility improves.
•Increases yields and quality by 25–30% while reducing investments by 20–25%.
Dosage & Application:
•Dosage: 5 litres per acre.
•Should be given by drip irrigation in the first stage (within 10–15 days after sowing).
•For short-term crops: 2 times during crop period.
•For long-term crops: 2 or 3 times a year.
•Five days before and after chemical fertilizers, avoid giving through drip irrigation.

3.2 GVAMSPF (Vesicular Arbuscular Mycorrhiza)
GVAM, employing its cutting-edge Bio-encapsulation technology, presents solid granules and
liquid formulations of mycorrhiza – a pivotal microorganism adept at efficiently retrieving es-
sential nutrients, particularly phosphorus, for plant roots. These granules and liquid variants
act as a vital conduit for plant sustenance. Within a mere gram or millilitre, a minimum of 10
mycorrhizal spores is encapsulated. Highly effective Bio-encapsulation (patented technology)
ensures the availability of these Mycorrhiza variants in both granular and liquid states.
Benefits:
•Significantly improves absorption of phosphorus from the soil through its intricate root
network, fostering plant growth even in soils with diminished phosphorus levels.
•Augments the population, contributing to enhanced nutrient uptake and overall plant vi-
tality.
•Acts as a shield, safeguarding plants from soil-borne diseases and resulting in healthier
crops.
Dosage & Application:
•Dosage: 10 kg per acre for granular form, 5 litres per acre for liquid form.
•Granular Form: Apply granules directly to the soil during final ploughing or when sowing
seeds.
•Liquid Form: Administer during the initial phase – either at planting or shortly thereafter.
8
Application Frequency:
•For short-duration crops: A single application during the cropping season is sufficient.
•For long-duration crops: Apply 1 to 2 times annually.
Caution:
•For granular form: Ensure thorough mixing during seedbed preparation.
•For liquid form: Apply directly to roots during planting or shortly afterwards.
3.3 N-Factor & P-Factor
3.3.1 N-Factor – Nitrogen Fixing Bacteria
N-Factor refers to free-living or endophytic bacteria that play a key role in stabilizing nitrogen
in the environment. In one millilitre of liquid, a minimum of 1x10 bacteria is present. These
bacteria, through release of various enzymes into the environment, convert atmospheric nitrogen
(N) into immediately absorbable forms such as ammonia (NH) or nitrate (NO) for plants.
Benefits:
•Stabilizes 20 to 40 kg of nitrogen per hectare, significantly enhancing nitrogen availability.
•Reduces need for chemical fertilizers by 25-30%.
•Stimulates release of auxins, gibberellic acid, and cytokinins, fostering plant growth.
•Improves moisture absorption capacity of plants from soil, resulting in 10-15% increase in
crop yield in rain-fed areas.
Dosage & Application:
•Dosage: 1 litre per acre.
•Initially, apply through seed treatment using seed-dip method, followed by foliar spray
during subsequent stages.
•In case of weather changes, apply 1 litre per acre as foliar spray.
Application Frequency:
•For short-duration crops: Single application per crop cycle.
•For mid-duration crops: Apply twice.
•For long-duration crops: Apply 2 to 3 times per crop cycle.
3.3.2 P-Factor – Phosphorus Solubilizing Bacteria
The P-Factor represents liquid living fertilizer, a potent blend of free-living and endophytic
bacteria designed to unlock the power of phosphorus in neutral soil conditions. With a con-
centration of at least 1x10 bacteria per millilitre, this solution harnesses the natural ability of
bacteria to solubilize phosphorus. Once applied, these bacteria seamlessly integrate into the
soil, releasing enzymes that dissolve inaccessible phosphorus and transform it into a readily
available form for plants.
9
Benefits:
•Provides a substantial yield of 25–30 kg of phosphorus per hectare, reducing reliance on
chemical fertilizers by 20–25%.
•Stimulates secretion of specific hormones and bio-chemicals in the root region, fostering
plant growth.
•Results in a significant boost in crop yield (15–20%), contributing to sustainable and
efficient agricultural practices.
Dosage & Application:
•Dosage: 1 litre per acre.
•Initiate via drip irrigation initially, followed by strategic spraying during subsequent stages.
•Apply during sowing or spraying for continuous release in crop root zone.
Application Frequency:
•For short-duration crops: Single application per crop cycle.
•For mid-duration crops: Apply twice.
•For long-duration crops: Apply 2 to 3 times per crop cycle.
3.4 K-FACTOR
K-factor refers to free-living or endophytic bacteria in the rhizosphere, which are responsible
for mobilizing potassium in the soil. In one millilitre of fluid, there are at least 1x10 bacteria.
These bacteria, after entering the soil, release a variety of organic acids and enzymes into the
root zone. As a result, they facilitate the assimilation of potassium, making it more available
to plants.
Advantages:
•Improves potassium availability to plants from early stages, promotes strong root develop-
ment, stem and tuber formation. In addition, it contributes to increase the arrangement
of flowers and fruits.
•Reduces the need for chemical potassium fertilizers by 20-25%.
•Exhibits antagonistic properties against various plant pathogens, contributes better disease
resistance, improves plant vigor and yield.
Dosage & Application:
•Dosage: 1 liter per acre.
•Initially, apply by seed treatment using seedling dipping method, followed by foliar spray
during growth stages.
Application Frequency:
•For short-duration crops, a single application per

of flowers and fruits.

•Exhibits antagonistic properties against various plant pathogens, contributes better disease

3.5 ZN-FACTOR
ZN-FACTOR represents free-living or endophytic bacteria within the rhizosphere that actively
participate in the solubilization of zinc in the soil. In one millilitre of liquid, a minimum of 1x10
bacteria can be identified. When introduced into the soil, these bacteria release various organic
acids and enzymes into the root zone, facilitating the solubilization of zinc and enhancing its
availability to plants.
Benefits:
•Enhances zinc accessibility to plants from the early growth stages, promoting robust root
development and improving stem and tuber formation. It also contributes to increased
flower and fruit setting.
•Reduces dependence on chemical zinc fertilizers by 20-25%.
•Exhibits antagonistic properties against various plant pathogens, thereby enhancing overall
disease resistance.
•Significantly contributes to the total zinc nutrient pool, thereby improving plant vigour
and yield.
Dosage & Application:
•Dosage: 1 litre per acre.
•Initially, apply through seed treatment using a seedling dip method, followed by foliar spray
during subsequent growth stages.
•In case of changes in weather conditions, apply 1 litre per acre through foliar spray.
Application Frequency:
•For short-duration crops, a single application during the crop cycle is recommended.
•For mid-duration crops, apply twice.
•For long-duration crops, apply 2 to 3 times per crop cycle.

3.10.1 PROCEED – Biotic & Abiotic Stress Relieve

per growth stage with specific micronutrients) specially formulated to provide major nutrients
(Nitrogen, Phosphorus and Potash at least 1.2%) and secondary(Calcium ,Magnesium,Sulphur)
and micro nutrients in required doses for the growth stage of the crop.

efficiency and the plant can fully utilize its genetic potential.

5 Biofactor’s chemical fertilizers:
Today the agricultural sector is facing harsher and more unpredictable weather conditions than
ever before. Similarly, the soil’s nutrient capacity and microbial population are reduced. Al-
though farmers use traditional chem ical fertilizers found in the market, the nutrient availability
and utilization efficiency of plants has decreased due to the high particle size of these nutrients.
To overcome these problems, Biofactor has developed the Microbe Metabolite Assisted Micron
Sized Par ticles (MAMSP) technology, which uses microbes to microsize the particle size. All
the products made using this technology have very small sized of nutrients. Thus the availability
and utilization efficiency of nutrients to plants increases. They work with three times higher
efficiency compared to regular fertilizers. Therefore the biofactor can get more results using less
quantity of their chemical nutrients

5.1 What does that mean?
The method of irrigating the field in which the nutrient solu tions are dropped by drop near
the water pipe or canal is called drop method.
5.2 What is the use?
Non-drip farmers cannot apply liquid nutrients through the soil. At such time, the nutrient
solution reaches the entire f ield evenly until the field is watered by providing it in drop mode

Description: Biological control mixture (Trichoderma viridae, Trichoderma harzianum, Pseu-
domonas fluorescens) for soil-borne and airborne diseases.
Mode of Action: Controls crop-damaging fungi via enzymes and secondary metabolites.
Types & Application
•Invictus V:Trichoderma viridae, 2×10 7 CFU/g. Controls root rot, damping off,Al-
ternaria,Colletotrichum,Cercospora, and other fungal diseases.
•Invictus H:Trichoderma harzianum, 2×10 7 CFU/g. Similar disease control as Invictus
V.
Application Methods
•Per Acre: 10 kg
•Seed Treatment: 40 g/kg seed + 50 ml water, dry 30 min in shade before sowing.
•Before Sowing: 50 g Invictus + 10 kg cattle manure + 1 kg neem flour; shade for 15 days
with intermittent water; then apply to 1-acre field.
•Seedling Plants: 100 g Invictus in 20 L water; submerge roots 30 min before planting.
•Main Field: 10 kg Invictus + 200 kg cattle manure + 20 kg neem flour; shade for 15 days,
sprinkle water intermittently, then apply to field.

OverviewInvictus is a novel soil-borne disease controller containing liveTrichoderma viride
culture (1.5% W.P.) with a minimum CFU count of 2×10 6/g. It effectively controls seed- and
soil-borne pathogens such asRhizoctonia solani,Fusarium,Pythium,Phytophthora,Verticillium,
Alternaria,Colletotrichum, andCercospora. It is safe, residue-free, and compatible with organic
systems.
Key Composition (Label Specs)
•Trichoderma viride:1.5%
•CFU Count:2×10 6 per gram (minimum)
•Carboxy Methyl Cellulose:1.5%
•Carrier (Talc):97%
Mechanism SummaryThe activeTrichoderma viridesuppresses pathogens via:
•Competitive exclusion:Outcompetes fungal pathogens for space and nutrients.
•Mycoparasitism:Directly parasitizes harmful fungi.
•Antifungal metabolites:Produces compounds that inhibit pathogen growth.
•Root zone colonization:Improves rhizosphere activity, enhancing plant vigor and dis-
ease resistance.
Crop Mapping (Examples)
•Tomato:Root rot, damping-off — before transplanting — 10 kg/acre with FYM.
•Okra:Seed/soil-borne diseases — before sowing — 10 kg/acre with FYM.
•Potato:Soil-borne rot — before planting — 10 kg/acre, soil drench.
•Chilli:Wilt, root rot — before transplanting — 10 kg/acre via drenching/bed treatment.

When to UseAfter ploughing and before planting or transplanting.
How to UseMix 10 kg Invictus with 2.5 tons/acre well-decomposed FYM; apply uniformly
across the soil.

StorageStore in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.

Irrigation  Method:   
Drip
 
Irrigation
 
vs.
 
Flood
 
Irrigation
 
Drip  irrigation  is  highly  recommended  and  superior  to  flood  irrigation  for  coconut  
cultivation.
 
Here's  why:  
1.  Water  Efficiency:  Drip  irrigation  delivers  water  directly  to  the  root  zone,  minimizing  waste  
due
 
to
 
evaporation,
 
runoff,
 
and
 
overspray.
 
It
 
can
 
save
 
60
 
to
 
70%
 
of
 
water
 
compared
 
to
 
traditional
 
methods
 
like
 
flood
 
irrigation.
 
2.  Increased  Yield  and  Profitability:  Studies  have  shown  that  drip-irrigated  coconut  farms  have  
higher
 
net
 
returns
 
and
 
better
 
benefit-cost
 
ratios
 
compared
 
to
 
flood-irrigated
 
farms,
 
primarily
 
due
 
to
 
increased
 
yield
 
and
 
better
 
production
 
efficiency.
 
3.  Reduced  Weed  Growth  and  Pest  Incidence:  By  applying  water  only  where  needed,  drip  
irrigation
 
discourages
 
weed
 
growth,
 
reducing
 
labor
 
for
 
weeding.
 
 
4.  Nutrient  Efficiency:  Fertilizers  can  be  applied  precisely  through  drip  irrigation  systems  
(fertigation),
 
ensuring
 
nutrients
 
reach
 
the
 
plant
 
roots
 
directly
 
and
 
uniformly.
 
5.  Conservation:  It  helps  conserve  water,  a  crucial  resource,  especially  with  increasing  water  
scarcity.
 
While  the  initial  setup  cost  for  drip  irrigation  might  be  higher  than  flood  irrigation,  the  
long-term
 
benefits
 
in
 
terms
 
of
 
water

reach
 
the
 
plant
 
roots
 
directly
 
and

While  the  initial  setup  cost  for  drip  irrigation  might  be  higher  than  flood  irrigation,  the

Role  of  Major  Nutrients  in  Coconut  
1.  Nitrogen:  Nitrogen  plays  an  important  role  in  the  growth  of  young  plants  and  rapid  spathe  
developemnt.

growing

When

and

fertilizers,

helps
 
the
 
roots
 
to
 
absorb
 
the
 
nitrogen
 
present
 
in

plants

to

ability

withstand
 
pests,

and
 
water
 
stress.

properly.

blade

Adding

to

cutting

etc.,
 
are
 
not
 
scientific

actions
 
harm
 
the
 
trees.
 
 
 
 
Inter-cultivation  
The  spaces  between  coconut  rows  should  be  cleanly  plowed  twice  a  year,  once  during  the  early  
monsoon
 
and
 
the
 
second
 
time
 
after
 
the
 
rainy
 
season.
 
This
 
helps
 
control
 
weeds.
 
Additional
 
income
 
can
 
be
 
obtained
 
by
 
cultivating
 
various
 
intercrops
 
in
 
these
 
spaces.
 
 
 
 
Damaging  the  roots  of  coconut  trees  by  tilling  too  close  to  the  base  is  harmful  and  does  not  
increase
 
yield.
 
Roots
 
are
 
essential
 
for
 
water
 
and
 
nutrient
 
uptake,
 
and
 
cutting
 
them
 
causes
 
stress,
 
weakens
 
the
 
tree,
 
and
 
makes
 
it
 
more
 
prone
 
to
 
pests
 
and
 
diseases.
 
This
 
stress
 
reduces
 
flowering
 
and
 
fruit
 
production,
 
leading
 
to
 
lower
 
yield
 
and
 
quality.
 
Even
 
if
 
the
 
tree
 
survives,
 
recovery
 
takes
 
time,
 
affecting
 
productivity
 
for
 
future
 
seasons.

Benefits  of  Organic  Manures  
1.  Helps  retain  moisture  for  a  longer  time,  especially  in  light  soils.     
2.  Increases  the  organic  carbon  content,  which  is  an  important  component  of  the  soil.     
3.  Increases  the  population  of  microorganisms  in  the  soil,  thereby  increasing  the  availability  
of
 
nutrients
 
to
 
the
 
plant
 
roots
 
in
 
the
 
soil.
 
 
 
 
4.  Reduces  high  levels  of  salts  and  alkalinity  in  the  soil.     
5.  Improves  the  physical  properties  of  the  soil.     
Using  organic  manures  in  coconut  orchards  every  year  gradually  increases  the  available  nutrients  
in
 
the
 
soil,
 
helping
 
the
 
plants
 
grow
 
well.
 
This
 
also
 
helps
 
maintain
 
soil
 
health.

4.  People  are  suggesting  use  of  micronutrients  like  boron  and  magnesium  along  with  
chemical
 
fertilisers
 
why?
 
Micronutrients  play  a  critical  role  in  coconut  cultivation  alongside  straight  fertilizers  (like  urea,  
superphosphate,
 
and
 
muriate
 
of
 
potash),
 
as
 
they
 
support
 
essential
 
physiological
 
functions
 
that
 
macronutrients
 
alone
 
cannot
 
fulfill.
 
While
 
NPK
 
fertilizers
 
help
 
in
 
plant
 
growth,
 
root
 
development,
 
and
 
nut
 
setting,
 
micronutrients
 
such
 
as
 
Boron,
 
Zinc,
 
Magnesium,
 
and
 
Copper
 
are
 
vital
 
for
 
processes
 
like
 
enzyme
 
activation,
 
pollen
 
viability,
 
chlorophyll
 
formation,
 
and
 
disease
 
resistance.  Deficiencies  can  lead  to  issues  like  immature  nut  fall,  button  shedding,  and  poor  
quality
 
copra.
 
For  optimal  growth  and  yield,  the  recommended  micronutrient  dosages  per  palm  per  year  are  as  
follows:
 
●  Boron  (as  Borax):  50  to  100  g  
 ●  Zinc  (as  Zinc  Sulphate):  100  to  200  g  
 ●  Magnesium  (as  Magnesium  Sulphate):  500  to1000  g  
 ●  Copper  (as  Copper  Sulphate):  50  to  100  g  
 ●  Iron  (as  Ferrous  Sulphate):  100  to  200  g  
 ●  Manganese  (as  Manganese  Sulphate):  100  to  200  g  
These  should  be  applied  in  split  doses  (preferably  twice  a  year)  along  with  FYM  or  compost,  and  
integrated
 
with
 
NPK
 
schedules
 
for
 
balanced
 
nutrition.
 
5.  Excess  button  shedding  in  coconut  is  observed  ,  why?  
Button  shedding  in  coconut  palms  is  caused  by:  poor  pollination,  moisture  stress,  nutrient  
deficiencies
 
(Boron,
 
Potassium,
 
Calcium),
 
pests/diseases
 
(red
 
palm
 
weevil,
 
rhinoceros
 
beetle,
 
fungal
 
infections),
 
high
 
temperature/drought,
 
waterlogging,
 
imbalanced
 
fertilizer
 
use
 
(excess
 
nitrogen),
 
and
 
genetic
 
factors.
 
Solutions  include:  proper  irrigation,  balanced  fertilizers  (NPK  500:320:1200g/tree/year;  200g  
Borax/tree/year),
 
foliar
 
sprays
 
(0.5%
 
Borax,
 
1%
 
Potassium
 
Sulphate),
 
pest/disease
 
management,
 
mulching,
 
growth
 
regulators
 
(NAA
 
20
 
ppm),
 
promoting
 
pollination,
 
and
 
drainage
 
management.

"hot"
 
than

manure,

more
 
slowly
 
and

more
 
gradual
 
release
 
of
 
nutrients.

soil
 
structure
 
effectively.

Plant  Protection  
Pests  
Among  the  pests  that  attack  coconut,  the  black-headed  caterpillar,  rhinoceros  beetle,  red  palm  
weevil,
 
leaf
 
caterpillar
 
(slug
 
caterpillar),
 
spiraling
 
whitefly,
 
and
 
eriophyid
 
mite
 
are
 
important.
 
 
 
 
Black-headed  Caterpillar  
The  black-headed  caterpillar  infests  coconut  trees  and  orchards  of  all  ages  (nurseries,  mature  
orchards,
 
bunds
 
of
 
paddy
 
fields,
 
banks
 
of
 
fish
 
ponds).
 
It
 
enters
 
the
 
lower
 
fronds
 
and
 
scrapes
 
and
 
eats
 
the
 
chlorophyll.
 
It
 
builds
 
nests
 
with
 
frass
 
resembling
 
sawdust
 
and
 
silk
 
threads,
 
sticking
 
the
 
leaflets
 
together,
 
and
 
resides
 
within
 
these
 
nests.
 
 
 
 
Symptoms/Damage  caused  by  Black-headed  Caterpillar:  
●  Dried  patches  appear  on  the  infested  leaves.     
●  As  the  infestation  increases,  the  patches  merge,  and  the  entire  leaf  dries  up.     
●  Thus,  all  the  leaves  on  the  tree  dry  up  and  droop.     
●  The  entire  orchard  looks  burnt.  In  severe  infestations,  the  nuts  can  also  be  damaged.     
●  When  young  plants  are  infested,  they  become  stunted  and  come  to  nut  formation  late.     
●  When  older  plants  are  infested,  the  chlorophyll  responsible  for  food  production  in  the  
leaves
 
is
 
eaten
 
away,
 
reducing
 
the
 
food
 
supply
 
to
 
the
 
plant,
 
leading
 
to
 
reduced
 
yield
 
and
 
nut
 
size.
 
 
 
 
●  Due  to  the  drying  of  leaves,  young  nuts  drop.  Spathes  fail  to  emerge,  reducing  yields.  It  
takes
 
2
 
to
 
3
 
years
 
for
 
the
 
tree
 
to
 
recover.
 
 
 
 
Life  Cycle:  The  adult  moth,  with  greyish  wings,  lays  eggs  near  old  galleries  on  the  lower  fronds.  
The
 
eggs
 
hatch
 
in
 
5
 
days,
 
and
 
the
 
small
 
caterpillars
 
start
 
feeding
 
on
 
the
 
leaves.
 
The
 
caterpillars
 
feed
 
within
 
the
 
leaf
 
folds
 
for
 
about
 
a
 
month.
 
They
 
pupate
 
within
 
cocoons
 
made
 
of
 
frass,
 
and
 
the
 
pupal
 
stage
 
lasts
 
10
 
to12
 
days,
 
after
 
which
 
the
 
adult
 
moth
 
emerges.
 
The
 
life
 
cycle
 
is
 
completed
 
in
 
about
 
six
 
weeks.
 
 
 
 
Management:  
●  Infested  and  dried  lower  leaves  should  be  removed  and  burnt.     
●  If  the  infestation  is  low  (pest  present  on  1  or  2  leaves),  release  the  parasitoid  Goniozus  
nephantidis
 
(10
 
individuals)
 
and
 
Bracon
 
brevicornis
 
(hebetor)
 
(20
 
individuals)
 
per
 
tree
 
on
 
10
 
percent
 
of
 
the
 
trees
 
in
 
the
 
orchard.
 
If
 
the
 
black-headed
 
caterpillar
 
infestation
 
is
 
high,
 
a
 
larger
 
number
 
of
 
parasitoids
 
need
 
to
 
be
 
released.
 
 
 
 
●  Since  this  pest  also  infests  palmyra  trees  in  the  vicinity  of  coconut  orchards,  parasitoids  
should
 
also
 
be
 
released
 
on
 
these
 
trees.

Rhinoceros  Beetle  
The  adult  rhinoceros  beetles  are  robust,  black  beetles  with  hard  wings.  They  are  called  
rhinoceros
 
beetles
 
because
 
they
 
have
 
a
 
horn
 
on
 
their
 
head
 
like
 
a
 
rhinoceros.
 
 
 
 
Symptoms  (Rhinoceros  Beetle):  Unopened,  mature  leaves  show  'V'  shaped  cuts.  Boreholes  
made
 
by
 
the
 
beetle
 
in
 
the
 
spindle,
 
and
 
chewed
 
fibrous
 
material
 
in
 
the
 
spindle
 
are
 
visible.
 
 
 
 
 
Damage:  
●  The  rhinoceros  beetle  bores  into  the  tender  spindle  portion  and  spathes,  damaging  
unopened
 
young
 
leaves
 
and
 
spathes,
 
thus
 
reducing
 
coconut
 
yields.
 
 
●  In  young  plants,  infestation  can  damage  the  spindle,  potentially  killing  the  plant.     
●  Besides  the  direct  damage,  the  beetle  spreads  bud  rot  disease  as  it  moves  from  tree  to  
tree.
 
 
 
 
●  Furthermore,  the  fermented  smell  emanating  from  the  damaged  spindle  attracts  the  Red  
Palm
 
Weevil,
 
which
 
can
 
cause
 
further
 
damage.
 
 
 
 
Life  Cycle:  White,  oval  eggs  are  laid  individually  2  to  6  inches  deep  in  moderately  moist  areas  
and
 
covered
 
with
 
surrounding
 
material.
 
By
 
the
 
time
 
they
 
hatch,
 
the
 
eggs
 
swell
 
and
 
change
 
color
 
to
 
yellow-brown.
 
Eggs
 
hatch
 
into

in
 
7
 
to
 
20
 
days.
 
A
 
single

beetle
 
lays
 
about
 
140
 
eggs
 
in
 
6
 
to
 
7
 
batches.
 
Eggs
 
are
 
laid
 
in
 
decaying
 
organic
 
matter
 
in
 
the
 
orchard,
 
dead
 
coconut
 
trees,
 
stumps,
 
etc..
 
The
 
grub
 
that
 
hatches
 
from
 
the
 
egg
 
is
 
white
 
with
 
hard
 
parts.
 
It
 
feeds
 
voraciously
 
on
 
organic
 
matter
 
and
 
reaches
 
the
 
pupal
 
stage
 
in
 
99
 
to
 
180
 
days.
 
To
 
pupate,
 
it
 
creates
 
a
 
smooth
 
chamber
 
and
 
turns
 
into
 
a
 
reddish-brown
 
pupa.
 
The
 
adult
 
beetle
 
emerges
 
from
 
the
 
pupal
 
stage
 
in
 
17
 
to
 
62
 
days.
 
It
 
remains
 
in
 
the
 
chamber
 
for
 
about
 
10
 
days
 
after
 
emerging
 
before
 
coming
 
out.
 
It
 
then
 
moves
 
around
 
the
 
spindles
 
of
 
coconut
 
trees
 
or
 
breeding
 
sites
 
like
 
dead
 
coconut
 
trees,
 
manure
 
heaps,
 
or
 
compost
 
pits,
 
living
 
for
 
more
 
than
 
200
 
days.
 
The
 
life
 
cycle
 
is
 
completed
 
in
 
about
 
130
 
to
 
196
 
days.
 
These
 
beetles
 
are
 
active
 
throughout
 
the
 
year,
 
causing
 
damage
 
to
 
trees.

Red  Palm  Weevil  
Damage  from  the  Red  Palm  Weevil  is  very  severe.  If  neglected,  the  entire  orchard  can  be  
destroyed.
 
Orchards
 
aged
 
5
 
to
 
10
 
years
 
are
 
often
 
most
 
susceptible
 
to
 
this
 
pest.
 
This
 
pest
 
is
 
also
 
more
 
common
 
in
 
orchards
 
where
 
banana
 
is
 
grown
 
as
 
an
 
intercrop.
 
Furthermore,
 
the
 
Red
 
Palm
 
Weevil
 
is
 
attracted
 
to
 
trees
 
that
 
have
 
died
 
due
 
to
 
bud
 
rot
 
or
 
lightning
 
strikes,
 
or
 
trees
 
whose
 
spindle
 
have
 
been
 
infested
 
by
 
the
 
rhinoceros
 
beetle.
 
The
 
weevil
 
is
 
also
 
attracted
 
to
 
wounds
 
on
 
the
 
stem
 
caused
 
by
 
tools,
 
root
 
pruning,
 
or
 
damage
 
to
 
the
 
base
 
during
 
plowing
 
with
 
a
 
tractor.
 
 
 
 
Symptoms:  
●  Leaves  in  the  middle  whorls  turn  yellow  or  dry  up.     
●  Thick,  dark  red  gum  oozes  from  boreholes  on  the  stem.  Chewed  fibrous  material  comes  
out
 
of
 
the
 
holes.
 
 
 
 
●  The  base  of  the  frond  splits  vertically.     
●  Cocoons  made  of  fiber  by  the  grub,  or  chewed  fibrous  material,  are  visible  in  the  leaf  
axils
 
or
 
at
 
the
 
base
 
of
 
the
 
tree.
 
 
 
 
●  If  you  place  your  ear  against  the  stem  of  an  infested  tree,  you  can  hear  the  sound  of  the  
grubs
 
inside
 
eating
 
the
 
stem.
 
 
 
 
Damage:  
●  The  pest  that  causes  a  vertical  splitting  at  the  base  of  the  stem  in  coconut  cultivation  is  
the
 
Red
 
Palm
 
Weevil
 
(
Rhynchophorus
 
ferrugineus
).
 
●  When  the  tree  is  partially  damaged,  growth  is  reduced,  and  nut  formation  is  delayed.     
●  When  the  trunk  becomes  completely  hollow,  the  tree  dies  and  falls  over.     
Life  Cycle:  Adult  weevils  lay  about  200  smooth,  shiny,  brownish  eggs  individually  in  cracks,  
cuts,
 
or
 
wounds
 
on
 
the
 
stem.
 
Within
 
2
 
to
 
5
 
days,
 
legless
 
grubs
 
hatch
 
from
 
the
 
eggs
 
and
 
feed
 
on
 
the  soft  tissue  inside  the  stem.  The  grubs  are  spindle-shaped  with  wrinkled  skin,  bulging  in  the  
middle,
 
thick,
 
brownish,
 
legless,
 
and
 
have
 
a
 
dark
 
red
 
head.
 
They
 
feed
 
for
 
two
 
to
 
three
 
weeks,
 
then
 
pupate,
 
and
 
emerge
 
as
 
adult
 
weevils.
 
The
 
life
 
cycle
 
takes
 
about
 
3
 
months
 
to
 
complete.
 
The
 
adult
 
weevil
 
lives
 
for
 
2
 
to
 
3
 
months.
 
 
 
 
Management:  
●  Immediately  cut  down,  split  open,  and  burn  trees  killed  by  this  pest.

mixture
 
of
 
100g

cake
 
+

sand.

banana
 
and
 
cocoa.
 
 
 
 
Management:  
●  Monitor  the  presence  of  adult  moths  using  light  traps  at  the  end  of  January  and  take  
appropriate
 
control
 
measures.
 
 
 
 
●  To  control  adult  slug  caterpillar  moths,  place  3  bulbs  of  200  watts  per  hectare  (two  and  a  
half
 
acres)
 
at
 
a
 
height
 
of
 
one
 
and
 
a
 
half
 
feet
 
above
 
the
 
ground,
 
with
 
a
 
water
 
trough
 
below,
 
to
 
attract
 
the
 
moths.
 
 
 
 
●  Hundreds  of  slug  caterpillars  pupate  in  the  fibrous  material  in  the  crown  and  leaf  axils  of  
the
 
coconut
 
tree.
 
Therefore,
 
clean
 
the
 
spindle
 
to
 
destroy
 
the
 
pupal
 
stages.
 
 
 
 
●  Cut  and  burn  infested  and  dried  leaves.  This  destroys  the  pupae  in  the  dormant  stage.     
●  When  adult  moths  are  present  in  the  orchard,  use  light  traps  to  attract  and  eliminate  large  
numbers
 
of
 
slug
 
caterpillar
 
moths.
 
 
 
 
●  When  slug  caterpillars  are  in  the  larval  stage,  release  the  parasitoid  Pediobius  imbrues  at  
the
 
rate
 
of
 
60
 
per
 
tree
 
every
 
15
 
days.
 
 
 
 
●  Spray  Chlorantraniliprole  18.5%  SC  at  0.3  ml/liter.  If  the  infestation  persists,  spray  B.t.  
(Bacillus
 
thuringiensis)
 
at
 
5
 
g/liter.
 
 
 
 
●  Trees  recover  quickly  if  irrigated  properly  and  fertilized  with  the  recommended  dose  (1  
kg
 
Urea,
 
2
 
kg
 
Single
 
Superphosphate,
 
2
 
kg
 
Muriate
 
of
 
Potash
 
per
 
tree).
 
 
 
 
Spiraling  Whitefly   
The  scientific  name  of  the  Rugose  spiraling  whitefly  is  Aleurodicus  rugioperculatus .  It  
was
 
first
 
reported
 
infesting
 
coconut
 
in
 
2016
 
in
 
Pollachi,
 
Tamil
 
Nadu,
 
and
 
Palakkad,
 
Kerala.
 
In
 
Andhra
 
Pradesh,
 
this
 
spiraling
 
whitefly
 
was
 
first
 
identified
 
on
 
coconut
 
trees
 
in
 
the
 
Kadiyam
 
region
 
of
 
East
 
Godavari
 
district
 
in
 
December
 
2016.
 
 
 
 
Symptoms:  
●  It  is  a  type  of  sap-sucking  winged  insect.     
●  It  lays  eggs  in  white  spiral  patterns  on  the  underside  of  leaves.  These  spirals  are  covered  
with
 
a
 
white
 
waxy
 
coating
 
and
 
hairs.
 
 
 
 
●  The  underside  of  the  leaves  becomes  covered  with  a  white  cottony  substance.     
●  Honey-like  sticky  substance  drips  from  the  underside

It  lays  eggs  in  white  spiral  patterns  on  the  underside  of  leaves.  These  spirals  are  covered  
with
 
a
 
white
 
waxy
 
coating
 
and
 
hairs.
 
 
 
 
●  The  underside  of  the  leaves  becomes  covered  with  a  white  cottony  substance.     
●  Honey-like  sticky  substance  drips  from  the  underside  of  the  leaves  onto  the  leaves  below,  
causing
 
them
 
to

Damage:  
●  Both  the  nymphal  and  adult  stages  of  the  whitefly  gather  on  the  underside  of  coconut  
leaves
 
and
 
suck
 
the
 
sap.
 
This
 
causes
 
stress
 
to
 
the
 
trees.
 
 
 
 
●  The  honey-like  sticky  substance  promotes  the  growth  of  a  black  sooty  mold  fungus  
belonging
 
to
 
the
 
genus
 
Capnodium
 
(specifically
 
mentioned
 
as
 
Leptoxyphium
).
 
 
 
 
●  The  sooty  mold  on  the  leaves  obstructs  photosynthesis.     
●  In  severe  whitefly  infestations,  not  only  the  leaves  but  also  the  petiole  bases  and  young  
coconuts
 
get
 
covered
 
with
 
the
 
white
 
cottony
 
substance.
 
 
 
 
Life  Cycle:  The  adult  female  lays  light  brown  or  dark  yellow  eggs  in  a  spiral  pattern  on  
the
 
underside
 
of
 
the
 
leaves.
 
This
 
whitefly
 
develops
 
through
 
five
 
stages.
 
The
 
spiraling
 
whitefly
 
is
 
about
 
five
 
times
 
larger
 
than
 
the
 
common
 
whitefly
 
(approx.
 
2.5
 
mm).
 
The
 
wings
 
of
 
the
 
spiraling
 
whitefly
 
have
 
irregular
 
light
 
brown
 
bands
 
spread
 
across
 
them.
 
Its
 
life
 
cycle
 
is
 
completed
 
in
 
about
 
40
 
to
 
45
 
days.
 
The
 
Rugose
 
whitefly
 
becomes
 
severe
 
under
 
drought
 
conditions.
 
They
 
cannot
 
tolerate
 
heavy
 
rain
 
and
 
humid
 
weather.
 
An
 
increase
 
in
 
temperature
 
by
 
two
 
degrees
 
Celsius
 
or
 
more
 
above
 
the
 
normal
 
summer
 
temperature
 
contributes
 
to
 
the
 
whitefly
 
outbreak.
 
 
 
 
Integrated  Management  of  Spiraling  Whitefly:  
●  Do  not  transport  coconut  seedlings  from  severely  infested  areas  to  other  regions.  If  export  
is
 
necessary,
 
inspect
 
thoroughly
 
to
 
ensure
 
the
 
absence
 
of
 
whitefly
 
before
 
transportation.
 
 
 
 
●  Tie  12  yellow  tarpaulin  sheets  per  acre  to  the  coconut  tree  trunks  and  apply  crude  castor  
oil
 
to
 
these
 
sheets.
 
The
 
adult
 
spiraling
 
whiteflies
 
get
 
stuck
 
to
 
the
 
sticky
 
tarpaulin
 
sheets.
 
Reapply
 
castor
 
oil
 
to
 
the
 
yellow
 
sheets
 
every
 
7
 
to
 
10
 
days.
 
 
 
 
●  The  natural  enemy,  the  parasitoid  Encarsia  guadeloupae ,  keeps  this  whitefly  under  
control.
 
Since
 
there
 
is
 
no
 
facility
 
for
 
laboratory
 
production
 
of
 
this
 
parasitoid,
 
collect
 
it
 
from
 
coconut
 
orchards
 
where
 
Encarsia
 
has
 
naturally
 
developed
 
and
 
release
 
it
 
in
 
whitefly-infested
 
areas
 
lacking
 
the
 
parasitoid.
 
These
 
parasitoids
 
bring
 
the
 
whitefly
 
under
 
control
 
in
 
about
 
6
 
to
 
8
 
months.
 
 
 
 
●  Since  the  Rugose  whitefly  is  an  invasive  alien  insect  in  our  country,  identify  it  and  
provide
 
complete
 
information
 
to
 
farmers
 
and
 
horticulture
 
department
 
officials.
 
Provide
 
appropriate
 
training
 
for
 
its
 
control.
 
 
 
 
●  Stop  the  use  of  insecticides  in  orchards  infested  with  spiraling  whitefly.  This  allows  
natural
 
enemies
 
like
 
parasitoids
 
to
 
multiply
 
and
 
control
 
the
 
whitefly.

of

Sooty  Mold  Management:  
●  The  black  sooty  mold  is  a  secondary  issue  caused  by  the  honeydew.  ●  Water  spray:  Applying  pressurized  water  can  help  wash  away  the  sooty  mold.  ●  Starch/Maida  paste  solution:  Spraying  1%  starch  solution  or  2.5%  maida  paste  solution

Disease  Management  
Among  the  diseases  affecting  coconut,  Ganoderma  (Basal  Stem  Rot/Red  Lac),  Stem  
Bleeding,
 
Bud
 
Rot,
 
Nut
 
Fall,
 
and
 
Leaf
 
Blight
 
caused
 
by
 
fungal
 
species
 
are
 
important.
 
Ganoderma  Disease  (Basal  Stem  Rot)  
Ganoderma  disease  is  a  major  and  very  dangerous  disease  affecting  coconut  orchards.  It  
is
 
also
 
known
 
as
 
'siga
 
tegulu',
 
'erralakka
 
tegulu'
 
(red
 
lac
 
disease),
 
'bankakaru
 
tegulu'
 
(gum
 
oozing
 
disease),
 
'pottulakka
 
tegulu'
 
(husk
 
lac
 
disease).
 
This
 
disease
 
is
 
more
 
prevalent
 
in
 
coconut
 
orchards
 
on
 
light
 
soils
 
than
 
on
 
black
 
soils.
 
Its
 
spread
 
is
 
also
 
extensive
 
in
 
light
 
soils.
 
It
 
is
 
observed
 
that
 
the
 
disease
 
spread
 
is
 
less
 
in
 
years
 
with
 
high
 
rainfall.
 
Generally,
 
weather
 
conditions
 
from
 
November
 
to
 
June
 
favor
 
the
 
spread
 
of
 
this
 
disease.
 
The
 
severity
 
and
 
spread
 
of
 
this
 
disease
 
are
 
higher
 
in
 
orchards
 
experiencing
 
significant
 
water
 
stress.
 
Farmers
 
commonly
 
practice
 
cutting
 
coconut
 
tree
 
roots,
 
which
 
should
 
not
 
be
 
done.
 
Cutting
 
coconut
 
roots
 
creates
 
wounds,
 
allowing
 
the
 
Ganoderma
 
fungus
 
spores
 
present
 
in
 
the
 
soil
 
to
 
infect
 
the
 
trees
 
through
 
the
 
wounded
 
roots.
 
 
 
 
Symptoms:  Ganoderma  disease  infects  coconut  through  fungal  spores  present  in  the  soil.  
Initially,
 
Ganoderma
 
attacks
 
the
 
roots
 
in
 
the
 
ground.
 
At
 
this
 
stage,
 
we
 
cannot
 
detect
 
the
 
disease.
 
After
 
a
 
significant
 
percentage
 
of
 
roots
 
rot,
 
the
 
disease
 
spreads
 
into
 
the
 
stem,
 
causing
 
complete
 
decay
 
of
 
the
 
tissues.
 
However,
 
this
 
rot
 
is
 
internal
 
within
 
the
 
ground
 
and
 
stem,
 
so
 
it
 
is
 
not
 
visible
 
externally.
 
Gradually,
 
the
 
disease
 
progresses
 
from
 
the
 
roots
 
into
 
the
 
stem.
 
At
 
this
 
stage,
 
oozing
 
of
 
a
 
thick,
 
gummy
 
liquid,
 
dark
 
brown
 
to
 
whitish
 
in
 
color,
 
can
 
be
 
observed
 
from
 
small
 
cracks
 
around
 
the
 
base
 
of
 
the
 
stem.
 
Due
 
to
 
the
 
complete
 
decay
 
of
 
the
 
stem
 
tissue,
 
the
 
tree
 
cannot
 
absorb
 
necessary
 
water
 
and
 
nutrients
 
from
 
the
 
soil.
 
At
 
this
 
stage,
 
gum
 
oozes
 
first
 
through
 
small
 
cracks
 
around
 
the

can
 
be
 
observed
 
from
 
small
 
cracks
 
around
 
the
 
base
 
of
 
the
 
stem.
 
Due
 
to
 
the
 
complete
 
decay
 
of
 
the
 
stem
 
tissue,
 
the
 
tree
 
cannot
 
absorb
 
necessary
 
water
 
and
 
nutrients
 
from
 
the
 
soil.
 
At
 
this
 
stage,
 
gum
 
oozes
 
first
 
through
 
small
 
cracks
 
around
 
the
 
base
 
of
 
the
 
stem.
 
This
 
gum
 
oozing
 
gradually
 
spreads
 
upwards.
 
The
 
leaves
 
of
 
the
 
infected
 
tree
 
turn
 
yellow,
 
wilt,
 
and
 
become
 
brownish.
 
Due
 
to
 
the
 
delayed
 
emergence
 
of
 
new
 
leaves,
 
the
 
number
 
of
 
leaves
 
on
 
the
 
diseased
 
tree
 
is
 
noticeably
 
reduced.
 
Similarly,
 
the
 
leaf
 
size
 
also
 
decreases.
 
In
 
Ganoderma-infected
 
coconut
 
plants,
 
the
 
number
 
of
 
flowers
 
significantly
 
decreases,
 
the
 
number
 
of
 
male
 
flowers
 
increases,
 
and
 
the
 
number
 
of
 
female
 
flowers
 
drastically
 
reduces.
 
Shedding
 
of
 
young
 
nuts
 
and
 
nuts
 
is
 
also
 
a
 
symptom
 
of
 
this
 
disease.
 
If
 
the
 
roots
 
of
 
an
 
infected
 
coconut
 
tree
 
are
 
observed,
 
they
 
appear
 
completely
 
rotten
 
and
 
turned
 
black.
 
In
 
severely
 
affected
 
trees,
 
about
 
70
 
percent
 
of
 
the
 
roots
 
are
 
rotten.
 
New
 
roots
 
do
 
not
 
develop.
 
If
 
neglected
 
even
 
slightly,
 
the
 
disease
 
intensifies,
 
the
 
tree
 
leaves
 
turn
 
yellow,
 
wilt,
 
and
 
reach
 
a
 
drooping
 
stage.
 
Later,
 
the
 
entire
 
crown
 
wilts,
 
and
 
the
 
tree
 
dries
 
up.
 
This
 
symptom
 
should
 
be
 
identified
 
as
 
Ganoderma
 
disease.
 
Subsequently,
 
these
 
dried
 
coconut
 
leaves
 
fall
 
off.
 
Due
 
to
 
the
 
complete
 
shedding
 
of
 
coconut
 
leaves,
 
the
 
stem
 
becomes
 
bare
 
and
 
looks
 
like
 
a
 
sharpened
 
pencil
 
tip.
 
The
 
tree
 
dies
 
within
 
the
 
next
 
5
 
to
 
6
 
months.
 
Sometimes,
 
mushrooms
 
sprout
 
on
 
the
 
bases
 
of
 
trees
 
in
 
the
 
final
 
stages
 
of
 
the
 
disease.
 
The
 
upper
 
surface
 
of
 
these
 
mushrooms
 
is
 
lac-colored.
 
The
 
lower
 
surface
 
is
 
white
 
or
 
greyish.
 
If
 
this
 
part
 
is
 
observed
 
carefully,
 
millions
 
of
 
microscopic
 
pores
 
are
 
visible.
 
From
 
these,
 
billions
 
of
 
disease-causing
 
fungal
 
spores
 
are
 
released
 
and
 
spread
 
through
 
the
 
air.
 
When
 
wet,
 
these
 
germinate,
 
grow
 
the
 
fungus,
 
and
 
infect
 
nearby
 
coconut
 
roots.
 
Therefore,
 
allowing
 
Ganoderma
 
disease
 
to
 
progress
 
until
 
mushrooms
 
form
 
is
 
extremely
 
dangerous.
 
We
 
often
 
observe
 
Ganoderma-infected
 
dead
 
trees
 
breaking
 
and
 
falling
 
at
 
the
 
base
 
during
 
strong
 
winds
 
in
 
coconut
 
orchards.
 
When
 
examining
 
these
 
fallen
 
coconut
 
logs,
 
the
 
inner
 
part
 
of
 
the
 
log
 
is
 
found
 
to
 
be
 
rotten
 
and
 
hollow.
 
 
 
 
Integrated  Management  Practices  including  Biological  Control  for  Ganoderma  
Disease:
 
●  As  soon  as  Ganoderma  symptoms  are  observed  in  the  orchard,  isolate  the  affected  area  by  
digging
 
a
 
trench
 
1
 
meter
 
deep
 
and
 
50
 
cm
 
wide
 
around
 
the
 
diseased
 
tree(s).
 
This
 
prevents
 
the
 
fungal
 
spores
 
near
 
the
 
roots
 
of
 
the
 
infected
 
trees
 
from
 
reaching
 
healthy
 
trees.
 
 
 
 
●  Uproot  dead  and  severely  infected  trees  along  with  their  roots  and  burn  them.  Otherwise,  
mushrooms
 
will
 
sprout
 
on
 
the
 
dead
 
tree
 
stems,
 
making
 
disease
 
control
 
difficult.
 
Burn
 
trash  and  grass  in  those  pits.  Under  no  circumstances  should  the  stumps  of  dead  trees  be  
left
 
in
 
the
 
orchard,
 
as
 
newly
 
planted
 
seedlings
 
may
 
die.
 
 
 
 
●  Before  replanting  seedlings  in  the  place  of  dead  trees,  expose  the  pits  to  sunlight  for  a  
week
 
to
 
ten
 
days
 
to
 
dry
 
thoroughly.
 
Then,
 
burning
 
trash

Bud  Rot  Disease  (Movvu  Kullu  Tegulu)  
Bud  rot  and  nut  rot  diseases  attack  and  damage  coconut  during  the  rainy  season.  Disease  
symptoms
 
are
 
likely
 
to
 
appear
 
with
 
the
 
onset
 
of
 
rains.
 
 
 
 
Bud  Rot  Symptoms:  In  infected  plants,  the  spear  leaf  (central  unopened  leaf)  and  the  
two
 
or
 
three
 
adjacent
 
leaves
 
initially
 
wilt.
 
Later,
 
other
 
secondary
 
organisms
 
invade,
 
causing
 
the
 
bud
 
to
 
rot
 
completely,
 
emitting
 
a
 
foul
 
odor.
 
If
 
this
 
leaf
 
is
 
pulled,
 
it
 
comes
 
off
 
easily.
 
This
 
rot
 
spreads
 
below
 
the
 
spear
 
leaf
 
and
 
attacks
 
the
 
single
 
growing
 
point
 
(apical
 
bud)
 
of
 
the
 
coconut
 
tree,
 
eventually
 
killing
 
the
 
bud
 
and
 
the
 
tree.
 
Sometimes,
 
even
 
though
 
the
 
bud
 
rots,
 
the
 
growing
 
point
 
survives,
 
and
 
new
 
leaves
 
emerge
 
after
 
a
 
few
 
months.
 
However,
 
these
 
leaves
 
are
 
often
 
stunted,
 
malformed,
 
with
 
burnt
 
edges.
 
Such
 
leaves
 
remain  compressed  by  the  fibrous  material  in  the  crown,  appearing  bushy.  If  control  
measures
 
are
 
not
 
taken
 
in
 
time,
 
this
 
disease
 
can
 
cause
 
severe
 
damage
 
to
 
coconut
 
orchards.
 
 
 
 
Precautions  for  Bud  Rot  Control:  
●  Farmers  should  take  preventive  measures  before  the  disease  occurs  rather  than  taking  
control
 
measures
 
after
 
infection.
 
 
 
 
●  Ensure  proper  drainage  in  the  orchard  to  prevent  water  stagnation.     
●  Remove  and  burn  trees  killed  by  the  disease.     
●  On  trees  affected  by  bud  rot,  remove  the  rotten  bud  and  the  adjacent  rotten  parts  and  burn  
them.
 
On
 
trees
 
with
 
stunted,
 
short
 
leaves,
 
cut
 
away
 
the
 
fibrous
 
material
 
in
 
the
 
crown
 
to
 
allow
 
leaves
 
to
 
emerge
 
easily.
 
 
 
 
●  Applying  potash  fertilizers  at  the  recommended  dose  regularly  increases  disease  
resistance
 
in
 
plants.
 
 
 
 
●  Remove  bunches  affected  by  nut  rot  and  spray  a  copper  fungicide  (Copper  Oxychloride)  
solution
 
(3
 
g
 
per
 
liter
 
of
 
water)

Coconut  root  feeding  is  a  valuable  technique  for  delivering  nutrients  and  pesticides  directly  to  
coconut,
 
offering
 
a
 
targeted
 
approach
 
to
 
address
 
specific
 
deficiencies
 
and
 
pest/disease
 
issues.

particularly
 
beneficial
 
for
 
its
 
efficiency,
 
reduced
 
chemical
 
wastage,
 
and
 
minimal
 
labor
 
requirements
 
compared
 
to
 
spraying.

How  to  Perform  Coconut  Root  Feeding:  
1.  Select  a  suitable  root:  Choose  a  fresh,  live,  fibrous  root  of  pencil  thickness.  Dark  brown  
colored
 
roots
 
are
 
generally
 
preferred.
 2.  Prepare  the  root:  Make  a  sharp,  slant  cut  at  the  end  of  the  selected  root.  Some  sources  
suggest
 
a
 
vertical
 
cut
 
to
 
prevent
 
rupturing
 
the
 
bag.
 3.  Prepare  the  solution:  Mix  the  chosen  chemical  (pesticide  or  nutrient  solution)  with  water  
in
 
a
 
polythene
 
bag.
 
The
 
bag
 
size
 
should
 
be
 
appropriate
 
(e.g.,
 
15
 
x
 
4
 
cm
 
for
 
40
 
cc
 
solution).
 4.  Insert  the  root:  Carefully  insert  the  cut  end  of  the  root  into  the  polythene  bag  containing  
the
 
solution.
 5.  Secure  the  bag:  Tie  the  mouth  of  the  polythene  bag  tightly  around  the  root  using  a  cotton  
thread
 
or
 
soft
 
wire
 
to
 
prevent
 
spillage.
 6.  Position  the  bag:  Bend  the  root  downwards  at  an  angle  (e.g.,  30°-40°)  and  secure  it  with  a  
forked
 
stick
 
or
 
by
 
digging
 
a
 
deep
 
enough
 
hole
 
to
 
create
 
space
 
below
 
the
 
root.
 
This
 
helps
 
in
 
absorption
 
and
 
prevents
 
spilling.
 7.  Monitor  absorption:  Allow  the  root  to  absorb  the  chemical  for  24  to  48  hours.  Check  if  
the
 
solution
 
has
 
been
 
absorbed.
 
If
 
not,
 
change
 
the
 
root
 
and
 
repeat
 
the
 
process.
 
8.  Harvesting  consideration:  It's  generally  recommended  to  harvest  mature  nuts  before  
administering
 
the
 
chemical.
 
After
 
root
 
feeding,
 
maintain
 
a
 
gap
 
of
 
at
 
least
 
45
 
days
 
before
 
the
 
next
 
harvest
 
of
 
nuts
 
to
 
ensure
 
chemical
 
residues
 
are
 
below
 
tolerance
 
limits.
 
Important  Note:  Maintain  a  distance  of  3.5  to  4  feet  from  the  trunk  when  applying  fertilizers  or  
nutrients
 
to
 
the
 
soil
 
around
 
the
 
feeding
 
roots.
 
Dig
 
a
 
shallow
 
basin,
 
apply
 
evenly,
 
and
 
water
 
thoroughly.

Latest  Information/Considerations:  
●  Integrated  Pest  Management  (IPM):  Root  feeding  should  be  part  of  a  broader  IPM  
strategy,
 
which
 
includes
 
cultural
 
practices
 
(field
 
sanitation,
 
proper
 
nutrition),
 
biological
 
control
 
(using
 
natural
 
enemies),
 
and
 
mechanical
 
methods
 
(trapping,
 
removal
 
of
 
infected
 
parts).
 ●  Residue  Analysis:  Research  on  chemical  residues  in  coconut  water  and  copra  after  root  
feeding
 
is
 
crucial
 
to
 
ensure
 
food
 
safety.
 
Studies
 
have
 
shown
 
that
 
residues
 
of
 
Tridemorph
 
applied
 
via
 
root
 
feeding
 
were
 
lower
 
than
 
tolerance
 
limits.
 ●  Resistance  Management:  Relying  on  a  single  chemical  for  root  feeding  can  lead  to  pest  or  
pathogen
 
resistance.
 
Rotating
 
chemicals
 
or
 
using
 
combinations
 
with
 
different
 
modes
 
of
 
action
 
is
 
advisable.
 ●  Biopesticides:  The  use  of  biopesticides  like  Azadirachtin  is  gaining  traction  for  root  
feeding
 
due
 
to
 
their
 
eco-friendly
 
nature
 
and
 
effectiveness
 
against
 
certain
 
pests.
 ●  Precision  Agriculture:  Future  research  may  focus  on  more  precise  methods  of  root  
feeding,
 
possibly
 
incorporating
 
sensor
 
technologies
 
to
 
monitor
 
nutrient
 
absorption
 
and
 
pest
 
activity.

recommendations
 
tailored
 
to

and
 
the

issues
 
affecting
 
your
 
coconut.
 
Trunk  Injection  
Yes,  trunk  injection  (also  known  as  endotherapy  or  vascular  injection)  is  a  recognized  and  
effective
 
method
 
for
 
treating
 
certain
 
pest
 
and
 
disease
 
problems
 
in
 
coconut
 
trees.
 
This
 
method
 
involves
 
directly
 
delivering
 
pesticides,
 
fungicides,
 
or
 
nutrients
 
into
 
the
 
tree's
 
vascular
 
system,
 
allowing
 
the
 
compounds
 
to
 
be
 
translocated
 
throughout
 
the
 
plant.
 
 
Advantages  of  Injection  Treatment:  
●  Targeted  Delivery:  The  chemical  is  delivered  directly  into  the  tree,  minimizing  
environmental
 
contamination
 
and
 
exposure
 
to
 
non-target
 
organisms
 
(humans,
 
wildlife,
 
beneficial
 
insects).
 ●  Reduced  Drift:  Unlike  spraying,  there  is  no  spray  drift,  making  it  safer  for  applicators  
and
 
surrounding
 
areas.
 ●  Effectiveness:  The  systemic  nature  of  the  treatment  ensures  the  chemical  reaches  the  
target
 
pest
 
or
 
disease
 
throughout
 
the
 
tree,
 
even
 
in
 
tall
 
coconut
 
plants
 
where
 
spraying
 
is
 
difficult.
 ●  Long-lasting:  In  many  cases,  injected  treatments  provide  longer-lasting  protection  
compared
 
to
 
external
 
applications.
 
Commonly  Used  Chemicals  and  Doses:  
The  specific  chemicals  and  doses  depend  on  the  pest  or  disease  being  targeted.  Here  are  some  
examples:
 
For  Pests  (e.g.,  Coconut  Rhinoceros  Beetle,  Red  Palm  Weevil,  Black-headed  caterpillar):  
●  Monocrotophos  (60%  EC):  This  is  a  systemic  insecticide  commonly  used  for  trunk  
injection.
 
 ○  Dose:  Typically,  10  to  20  ml  of  undiluted  Monocrotophos  (60%  EC)  per  palm.  
Some
 
recommendations
 
suggest
 
10
 
ml
 
mixed
 
with
 
500
 
ml
 
of
 
water
 
for
 
pouring
 
into
 
the
 
spindle
 
of
 
young
 
coconut
 
plants,
 
or
 
20
 
ml
 
mixed
 
with
 
an
 
equal
 
amount
 
of
 
water
 
for
 
root
 
feeding.
 
For
 
trunk
 
injection,
 
10
 
ml
 
undiluted
 
is
 
often
 
mentioned.
 ○  Note:  Monocrotophos  is  highly  toxic  and  its  use  may  be

and

IMA-jet
 
10
 
can

used
 
for

preventative
 
and

control
 
of

 ●  Emamectin  Benzoate:  Effective  against  various  pests,  including  CRB.

black-headed
 
caterpillar.
 
 ○  Dose:  All  dilutions  of  Cartap  Hydrochloride  50%  SP  injected  into  the  base  of  the  
coconut
 
palm
 
effectively
 
achieved
 
100%
 
larval
 
mortality
 
for
 
up
 
to
 
90
 
days.
 
For  Diseases  (e.g.,  Bud  Rot,  Basal  Stem  Rot):  
●  Fungicides  (e.g.,  Fosetyl-Al,  Potassium  Phosphite,  Copper  oxychloride,  Mancozeb):  ○  Fosetyl-Al:  Effective  against  bud  rot  caused  by  Phytophthora  species.  ■  Dose:  Injections  of  Fosetyl-Al  have  been  effective  in  controlling  bud  rot,  
with
 
annual
 
injections
 
being
 
the
 
norm,
 
though
 
intervals
 
can
 
be
 
up
 
to
 
three
 
years.
 ○  Potassium  Phosphite:  Also  effective  against  Phytophthora  species  and  can  
stimulate
 
plant
 
defense
 
mechanisms.
 
 ■  Dose:  Studies  have  used  30  mL  (8.4  g  a.i.),  60  mL  (16.8  g  a.i.),  and  90  mL  
(25.2
 
g
 
a.i.)
 
of
 
potassium
 
phosphite
 
diluted
 
1:2
 
with
 
deionized
 
water.
 ○  Aureofunginsol  +  Copper  Sulphate:  For  Basal  Stem  Rot  (Ganoderma  lucidum).  ■  Dose:  2g  Aureofunginsol  +  1g  Copper  Sulphate  in  100  ml  of  water.  This  is  
usually
 
applied
 
through
 
stem
 
injection
 
or
 
root
 
feeding
 
quarterly
 
for
 
one
 
year.
 ○  Tridemorph:  Also  for  Basal  Stem  Rot.  ■  Dose:  2ml  in  100ml  of  water,  applied  quarterly  for  one  year  through  stem  
injection
 
or
 
root
 
feeding.
 
Precautions  to  be  Taken:  
1.  Read  the  Label  Carefully:  Always  follow  the  specific  instructions,  dosage  rates,  and  
safety
 
precautions
 
provided
 
on
 
the
 
pesticide/fungicide
 
label.
 
This
 
is
 
paramount
 
for
 
effectiveness
 
and
 
safety.
 2.  Personal  Protective  Equipment  (PPE):  Wear  appropriate  PPE,  including  gloves,  eye  
protection,
 
long-sleeved
 
shirts,
 
and
 
pants,
 
to
 
prevent
 
skin
 
and
 
eye
 
exposure.
 
Respirators
 
might
 
be
 
necessary
 
for
 
certain
 
chemicals.
 3.  Timing  of  Application:  
○  For  pests,  treatment  is  most  effective  during  the  early  stages  of  infestation.  ○  For  diseases  like  bud  rot,  prophylactic  sprays  or  injections  before  the  onset  of  
monsoon
 
are
 
often
 
recommended.
 4.  Harvesting  Nuts:  If  the  infested  palm  bears  nuts,  harvest  all  mature  nuts  before  
insecticide
 
application.
 
Some
 
insecticides
 
have
 
a
 
waiting
 
period
 
(e.g.,
 
45
 
days)
 
before
 
nuts
 
can

rot,  prophylactic  sprays  or  injections  before  the  onset  of  
monsoon
 
are
 
often
 
recommended.
 4.  Harvesting  Nuts:  If  the  infested  palm  bears  nuts,  harvest  all  mature  nuts  before  
insecticide
 
application.
 
Some
 
insecticides
 
have
 
a
 
waiting
 
period
 
(e.g.,

before
 
nuts

 5.  Drilling  and  Injection  Technique:  ○  Use  a  clean,  sharp  drill  bit  (e.g.,  13  mm  diameter)  to  make  holes  at  a  45°  angle,  
about
 
1
 
meter
 
above
 
ground
 
level
 
and
 
10
 
cm
 
deep.
 
Make
 
two
 
holes
 
on
 
opposite
 
sides
 
of
 
the
 
trunk
 
for
 
systemic
 
distribution.
 ○  Ensure  the  holes  are  sealed  after  injection  to  prevent  leakage  and  promote  healing.  
Dowels
 
or
 
appropriate
 
sealants
 
can
 
be
 
used.
 ○  Sterilize  tools  with  diluted  bleach  before  and  after  use  to  prevent  the  transfer  of  
disease
 
pathogens.
 6.  Avoid  Overdosing:  Using  higher  than  recommended  doses  can  harm  the  tree  and  lead  to  
unnecessary
 
chemical
 
residues.
 7.  Environmental  Considerations:  ○  While  injection  reduces  environmental  exposure  compared  to  spraying,  dispose  of  
chemical
 
containers
 
properly.
 ○  Be  aware  of  any  local  regulations  or  bans  on  specific  chemicals.  8.  Professional  Guidance:  For  severe  infestations  or  unfamiliar  situations,  consult  with  
agricultural
 
experts
 
or
 
plant
 
protection
 
specialists.
 
They
 
can
 
provide
 
accurate
 
diagnosis
 
and
 
recommend
 
the
 
most
 
suitable
 
treatment
 
plan.
 9.  Tree  Health:  Trunk  injection  causes  a  permanent  wound.  This  method  is  generally  
recommended
 
for
 
prevention
 
of
 
lethal
 
diseases
 
or
 
control
 
of
 
significant
 
pest
 
outbreaks.
 
Consider
 
the
 
overall
 
health
 
and
 
vigor
 
of
 
the
 
tree
 
before
 
applying
 
injections.
 
By  adhering  to  these  guidelines,  injection  treatment  can  be  a  safe  and  highly  effective  method  for  
managing
 
pests
 
and
 
diseases
 
in
 
coconut
 
trees.

Based  on  your  description,  the  pest  you're  likely  dealing  with  in  your  coconut  plantation  is  the  
Coconut
 
Leaf
 
Caterpillar
.
 
Here's  why:  
●  Dried  spots  on  leaves  leading  to  complete  drying:  The  larvae  of  the  coconut  leaf  
caterpillar
 
(especially
 
Opisina
 
arenosella
,
 
also
 
known
 
as
 
the
 
black-headed
 
caterpillar)
 
scrape
 
the
 
green
 
matter
 
from
 
the
 
leaves,
 
leaving
 
behind
 
dried,
 
brown
 
patches
 
that
 
eventually
 
cause
 
the
 
entire
 
leaf
 
to
 
wither
 
and
 
look
 
"burnt."
 
●  Entire  plantation  looking  burnt:  A  severe  infestation  can  make  the  whole  plantation  
appear
 
scorched
 
due
 
to
 
widespread
 
leaf
 
damage.
 ●  Caterpillars  scraping  and  eating  leaves  from  underneath:  This  is  a  classic  symptom  
of
 
the
 
coconut
 
leaf
 
caterpillar.
 
The
 
caterpillars
 
feed
 
from
 
the
 
underside
 
of
 
the
 
leaflets,
 
often
 
within
 
silken
 
galleries
 
or
 
tunnels
 
they
 
construct.
 
This  pest  can  cause  significant  damage  if  not  managed  effectively.

Causal  Organism:  Thanjavur  Wilt  is  primarily  caused  by  the  soil-borne  fungi  Ganoderma  
lucidum
 
and
 
Ganoderma
 
applanatum
.
 
Symptoms:  The  disease  progresses  through  distinct  stages,  often  leading  to  the  death  of  the  palm  
within
 
6
 
to
 
54
 
months
 
(average
 
24
 
months)
 
from
 
the
 
appearance
 
of
 
bleeding
 
patches.
 
●  Initial  Symptoms  (Stage  I):  ○  Wilting  and  yellowing  of  the  outermost  whorl  of  leaves,  which  may  not  always  be  
prominent.
 ○  Decay  and  death  of  fine  roots.  ●  Intermediate  Stages  (Stage  II  &  III):  
○  Bleeding  Patches:  Characteristic  reddish-brown  liquid  exudes  from  cracks  at  the  
base
 
of
 
the
 
stem,
 
near
 
the
 
ground
 
level,
 
gradually
 
extending
 
upwards.
 
The
 
tissues
 
beneath
 
these
 
patches
 
are
 
soft
 
and
 
decaying.
 ○  Extensive  root  decay  and  discoloration  (roots  become  watery  with  an  alcoholic  
smell,
 
red
 
below
 
the
 
hypodermis,
 
and
 
brownish
 
towards
 
the
 
stele).
 ○  Reduction  in  the  production  of  new  bunches  and  heavy  button  shedding.  ○  Drooping  of  lower  leaf  whorls.  ○  Nuts  become  barren.  ●  Advanced  Stages  (Stage  IV  &  V):  ○  Stem  decay  extends  upwards,  and  the  lowest  leaf  whorls  dry  and  fall  off.  ○  Other  leaves  also  droop,  leaving  only  the  spindle  leaf  and  a  few  young  leaves  
erect.
 ○  Eventually,  all  leaves  droop  and  fall,  leaving  a  shriveled,  dried,  decapitated  stem.  ○  Sporophores  (bracket  formations)  of  Ganoderma  may  appear  at  the  base  of  the  
trunk.
 ○  Scolytid  beetles  ( Xyleborus  perforans )  and  weevils  ( Diocalandra  stigmaticollis )  
are
 
often
 
found
 
boring
 
into
 
the
 
stem
 
at
 
bleeding
 
patches
 
in
 
later
 
stages,
 
accelerating
 
palm
 
demise.
 
Spread:  
●  Mainly  through  root  contact  between  diseased  and  healthy  coconut  plants.  ●  Favored  by  repeated  ploughing  and  uncontrolled  flood  irrigation.  ●  More  common  in  sandy  or  sandy  loam  soils,  neglected  plantations,  and  in  areas  with  old  
infections.

Symptoms:  Tatipaka  disease  primarily  affects  coconut  plants  in  the  20  to  60  year  age  group;  
young
 
coconut

are

●  Underground  Symptoms:  Reduction  in  the  number  and  size  of  roots,  and  extensive  root  
rot.
 ●  Above-ground  Symptoms:  ○  Tapering  of  the  stem  below  the  spindle.  ○  Reduction  in  the  size  and  number  of  leaves.  ○  Reduction  in  the  number  of  bunches  and  overall  spindle  size.  ○  Abnormal  shedding  of  buttons  and  immature  nuts.  ○  The  nuts  from  diseased  coconut  plants  have  thinner  husks,  weaker  fibers,  and  the  
copra
 
remains
 
soft
 
and
 
flexible
 
instead
 
of
 
drying
 
into
 
hard
 
copra.
 ○  Tender  coconut  water  from  affected  coconut  plants  can  be  insipid.  
Spread:  
●  It  is  believed  to  be  spread  by  insect  vectors,  though  specific  vectors  for  Tatipaka  are  not  
always
 
explicitly
 
mentioned
 
in
 
general
 
coconut
 
disease
 
management.
 
Phytoplasmas
 
are
 
typically
 
vector-borne.

Pradesh,
 
after
 
a
 
cyclone
 
in

especially
 
if

incidence

in

disease-resistant
 
varieties.
